Graphical abstract

Complex 1 shows a unique 2D extended structure based on macrocycle units of which 1D purely inorganic [Ag(NO3)] n  helical chains are formed, and complex 2 is a 1D chain structure with Ag-S bonding interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp015" view="all">Reaction of 4,4′-di(3-pyridyl-4-pyrimidinyl) disulfide (<ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold>) with AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> leads to a unique 2D extended structure {[Ag(<ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold>)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) based on [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] macrocycle units, of which 1D inorganic [Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> helical chains are generated. By contrast, definite Ag–S bonding interactions associated with the disulfide function have been established in {[Ag(<ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold>)]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), which is assembled of 4,4′-di(2-pyridyl-4-pyrimidinyl) disulfide (<ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold>) with AgClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>. Solid state luminescent properties of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are also examined.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Reaction of 4,4'-di(3-pyridyl-4-pyrimidinyl) disulfide (3-PPDS) with AgNO3 leads to a unique 2D extended structure {[Ag(3-PPDS)(NO3)]} n  (1) based on [Ag2(3-PPDS)2] macrocycle units, of which 1D inorganic [Ag(NO3)] n  helical chains are generated. By contrast, definite Ag-S bonding interactions associated with the disulfide function have been established in {[Ag(2-PPDS)]ClO4} n  (2), which is assembled of 4,4'-di(2-pyridyl-4-pyrimidinyl) disulfide (2-PPDS) with AgClO4. Solid state luminescent properties of complexes 1 and 2 are also examined.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Over the past few years, heterocyclic disulfides as organic building blocks have received more and more attention in the field of crystal engineering, among which 4,4′-dipyridyldisulfide (<ce:bold>4-dpds</ce:bold>) and 2,2′-dipyridyldisulfide (<ce:bold>2-dpds</ce:bold>) have been much studied . Their structural characteristics include (1) semi-rigid conformation with the C–S–S–C torsion angle of approximately 90° even when coordinated to metal ions; (2) axial chirality with <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>- and <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>-enantiomers, which is of particular interest in terms of chiral crystal engineering. Furthermore, diverse <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> reactions of the disulfide function (–S–S–) are becoming a promising tool towards fascinating metallosupramolecular architectures . Besides, despite the fact that the disulfide function is labile to coordinate with soft metal ions (e.g. Ag<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>) under suitable conditions, examples concerning this issue remain scarce hitherto . Considering the potential function of organic–metal–sulfur compounds such as electrical conductivity and photoluminescent properties , metal–disulfide complexes bearing metal–sulfur bonds should be deserved more attention.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past few years, heterocyclic disulfides as organic building blocks have received more and more attention in the field of crystal engineering, among which 4,4'-dipyridyldisulfide (4-dpds) and 2,2'-dipyridyldisulfide (2-dpds) have been much studied . Their structural characteristics include (1) semi-rigid conformation with the C-S-S-C torsion angle of approximately 90° even when coordinated to metal ions; (2) axial chirality with P- and M-enantiomers, which is of particular interest in terms of chiral crystal engineering. Furthermore, diverse in situ reactions of the disulfide function (-S-S-) are becoming a promising tool towards fascinating metallosupramolecular architectures . Besides, despite the fact that the disulfide function is labile to coordinate with soft metal ions (e.g. Ag+, Cu+) under suitable conditions, examples concerning this issue remain scarce hitherto . Considering the potential function of organic-metal-sulfur compounds such as electrical conductivity and photoluminescent properties , metal-disulfide complexes bearing metal-sulfur bonds should be deserved more attention.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">We have focused on the coordination chemistry of 4,4′-di(<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-pyridyl-4-pyrimidinyl) disulfide (<ce:bold>
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:bold>
<ce:bold>-PPDS</ce:bold>, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, 3, 4) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>) in recent years. In this context, we have described the structures of metallosupramolecular Zn(II) and Fe(II) complexes with <ce:bold>4-PPDS</ce:bold>
 and uncovered versatile <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> reactions of <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> triggered by metal coordination . As continuation of our work, we have investigated the self-assembly of <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold> with AgX salts (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) to further understand their coordination chemistry.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We have focused on the coordination chemistry of 4,4'-di(n-pyridyl-4-pyrimidinyl) disulfide ( n  -PPDS, n =2, 3, 4) ( ) in recent years. In this context, we have described the structures of metallosupramolecular Zn(II) and Fe(II) complexes with 4-PPDS  and uncovered versatile in situ reactions of 2-PPDS triggered by metal coordination . As continuation of our work, we have investigated the self-assembly of 2-PPDS and 3-PPDS with AgX salts (X=NO3 -, ClO4 -) to further understand their coordination chemistry.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General procedure</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">All chemicals and solvents were in analytical grade and used as commercially available. <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold> ligands were prepared according to our previous work . All procedures for syntheses and measurements of the silver (I) complexes were conducted in the dark unless otherwise stated. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were performed on a CHN–O-Rapid analyzer and an Elementar Vario MICRO analyzer. Infrared spectra were performed on a Nicolet 200 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region. The luminescent spectra for the solid samples were recorded at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrophotometer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedure

All chemicals and solvents were in analytical grade and used as commercially available. 2-PPDS and 3-PPDS ligands were prepared according to our previous work . All procedures for syntheses and measurements of the silver (I) complexes were conducted in the dark unless otherwise stated. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were performed on a CHN-O-Rapid analyzer and an Elementar Vario MICRO analyzer. Infrared spectra were performed on a Nicolet 200 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400-4000cm-1 region. The luminescent spectra for the solid samples were recorded at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrophotometer.

elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Ag(3-PPDS)(NO3)] n  (1) and [Ag(2-PPDS)(ClO4)] n  (2)

A colorless solution of AgNO3 (0.017g, 0.1mmol) in CH3CN (5mL) was carefully layered above a solution of 3-PPDS (0.039g, 0.1mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5mL). After 3 days light-yellow crystals were produced. Yield 61% (based on AgNO3). Anal. Calc. for C18H12AgN7O3S2: C, 39.57; H, 2.21; N, 17.95. Found: C, 39.52; H, 2.39; N, 17.75%. ν max/cm-1 3069m, 1593s, 1564s, 1537m, 1481m, 1430s, 1338s, 1203s, 1181s, 1038m, 1027m, 824s, 811s, 719s, 701s, 641s, 503w.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Diffraction intensities for complexes 1 and 2 were collected at 298(2)K on a Bruker SMART CCD-4K diffractometer employing graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The data were collected using SMART and reduced by the program Saint . All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares method on     F   obs   2     by using Shelxtl-PC software package . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, whereas all hydrogen atoms were calculated by geometrical methods and refined as a riding model. The crystallographic data for complexes 1 and 2 are listed in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in .

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Macrocycle structures have been obtained by assembling <ce:bold>4-dpds</ce:bold> with several metal ions (e.g. Pt, Ir, Co, Ni) , but Ag(I)-based macrocycles are still less known. <ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and two N atoms from two <ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold> ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>(a)). Both Ag–O and Ag–N bond lengths are within the normal range, and the C–S–S–C torsion angle (89.55°) is comparable to that of the free <ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold> ligand (81.33°) as expected . Moreover, the macrocycle cavity has its dimension of 7.34<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å measured by Ag⋯Ag and S–S⋯S–S separations. As most examples in literatures , complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also crystalizes in a non-chiral space group (<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/1) due to the presence of 1:1 macrocycle enantiomers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure description of complexes 1 and 2 

Macrocycle structures have been obtained by assembling 4-dpds with several metal ions (e.g. Pt, Ir, Co, Ni) , but Ag(I)-based macrocycles are still less known. Interestingly, assembly between AgNO3 and 3-PPDS generated complex 1 containing 2:2 M:L macrocycle units, of which each Ag atom is five-coordinated by three O atoms from two NO3 - anions and two N atoms from two 3-PPDS ligands ( (a)). Both Ag-O and Ag-N bond lengths are within the normal range, and the C-S-S-C torsion angle (89.55°) is comparable to that of the free 3-PPDS ligand (81.33°) as expected . Moreover, the macrocycle cavity has its dimension of 7.34×13.01Å measured by Ag⋯Ag and S-S⋯S-S separations. As most examples in literatures , complex 1 also crystalizes in a non-chiral space group (P2/1) due to the presence of 1:1 macrocycle enantiomers.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Remarkably, each macrocycle unit is further linked to four neighboring ones to give a 2D extended structure through <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>-2 bridging NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions. More strikingly, 1D right- and left-handed purely inorganic [Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> helical chains are alternatively arrayed along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis ((b)), which are generated from <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>-2 NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions bridging Ag(I) atoms. The helicity of [Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> inorganic chains is believed to be conferred by the intrinsic axial chirality of <ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold> ligands. Finally, it is noted that both helix and macrocycle motifs present in a single structure are rarely described as far as we know.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Remarkably, each macrocycle unit is further linked to four neighboring ones to give a 2D extended structure through μ-2 bridging NO3 - anions. More strikingly, 1D right- and left-handed purely inorganic [Ag(NO3)] n  helical chains are alternatively arrayed along b axis ((b)), which are generated from μ-2 NO3 - anions bridging Ag(I) atoms. The helicity of [Ag(NO3)] n  inorganic chains is believed to be conferred by the intrinsic axial chirality of 3-PPDS ligands. Finally, it is noted that both helix and macrocycle motifs present in a single structure are rarely described as far as we know.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">As aforementioned, the disulfide function tends to coordinate to soft metal ions according to HSAB theory (HSAB<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>hard-soft acid–base). However, there is only one example describing such bonding interactions, which is involved with <ce:bold>2-dpds</ce:bold> and CuClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
. If taking into account structural difference between <ce:bold>2-dpds</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4-dpds</ce:bold>, it may be inferred that the close proximity between N and S atoms in <ce:bold>2-dpds</ce:bold> promote metal–disulfide interactions. With this in mind, we choose <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> as the candidate given that the N,N-chelation of <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> may restrict the Ag atom in space close to the disulfide function. In our previous study, we have noticed that <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> is readily subject to <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> S–S reactions induced by metal coordination. Consequently, we first examined the stability of <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> in the presence of AgX salts (X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) with our reported method , and found that <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> can remain intact. Unfortunately, growing single crystals are only achieved in the case of AgClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> largely because of the rapid reaction between <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> and AgX.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As aforementioned, the disulfide function tends to coordinate to soft metal ions according to HSAB theory (HSAB=hard-soft acid-base). However, there is only one example describing such bonding interactions, which is involved with 2-dpds and CuClO4 . If taking into account structural difference between 2-dpds and 4-dpds, it may be inferred that the close proximity between N and S atoms in 2-dpds promote metal-disulfide interactions. With this in mind, we choose 2-PPDS as the candidate given that the N,N-chelation of 2-PPDS may restrict the Ag atom in space close to the disulfide function. In our previous study, we have noticed that 2-PPDS is readily subject to in situ S-S reactions induced by metal coordination. Consequently, we first examined the stability of 2-PPDS in the presence of AgX salts (X=NO3 -, ClO4 -, BF4 -) with our reported method , and found that 2-PPDS can remain intact. Unfortunately, growing single crystals are only achieved in the case of AgClO4 largely because of the rapid reaction between 2-PPDS and AgX.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Albeit its poor quality, X-ray diffraction analysis unambiguously indicates that Ag–S bonding interactions have been established in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. As depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, each Ag(I) atom is bound to two set of NNS donor atoms from two <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> ligands with Ag–S bond distances of 2.753(4) and 2.729(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are far shorter than the sum of Van der Waals radius of Ag and S atoms (3.52<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Compared with the free <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold>, the S–S distance (2.016(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is almost unchanged while the C–S–S–C torsion angle is altered significantly from 82.7° to 99.7° . Particularly, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has two types of five-membered chelated rings (CNAgNC and CNAgSS) sharing one common Ag–N edge. If treating the two fused five-membered rings as the repeating unit, the linkage between adjoining units could be classified into two types (1) sharing one common S–S edge with the Ag–S–S–Ag torsion angle of approximately 115.5°; (2) sharing one common Ag vertex with the S–Ag–S angle of 95.8°. Alternative use of two linkages produces a 1D extended structure, of which a unique Ag⋯S–S⋯Ag⋯S–S⋯Ag inorganic chain is resulted with the nearest Ag⋯Ag separation of about 5.71<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Albeit its poor quality, X-ray diffraction analysis unambiguously indicates that Ag-S bonding interactions have been established in complex 2. As depicted in  , each Ag(I) atom is bound to two set of NNS donor atoms from two 2-PPDS ligands with Ag-S bond distances of 2.753(4) and 2.729(3)Å, which are far shorter than the sum of Van der Waals radius of Ag and S atoms (3.52Å). Compared with the free 2-PPDS, the S-S distance (2.016(4)Å) of 2-PPDS in complex 2 is almost unchanged while the C-S-S-C torsion angle is altered significantly from 82.7° to 99.7° . Particularly, complex 2 has two types of five-membered chelated rings (CNAgNC and CNAgSS) sharing one common Ag-N edge. If treating the two fused five-membered rings as the repeating unit, the linkage between adjoining units could be classified into two types (1) sharing one common S-S edge with the Ag-S-S-Ag torsion angle of approximately 115.5°; (2) sharing one common Ag vertex with the S-Ag-S angle of 95.8°. Alternative use of two linkages produces a 1D extended structure, of which a unique Ag⋯S-S⋯Ag⋯S-S⋯Ag inorganic chain is resulted with the nearest Ag⋯Ag separation of about 5.71Å ( ).

<ce:section-title>Luminescent properties of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Solid state luminescent properties were examined for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at room temperature (see ). Upon excitation at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows the maximal emission at 379<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which is considered to be the result of the intraligand transition of <ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold> (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">em</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>383<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm). Differently, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays an intense emission with the maximum peak at 404<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with an evident red-shift compared with the <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> ligand (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">em</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>389<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm). One probable reason for the lower energy emission of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may be ascribed to the presence of Ag–S bonding interactions, which is presumably originated from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties of complexes 1 and 2 

Solid state luminescent properties were examined for complexes 1 and 2 at room temperature (see ). Upon excitation at 300nm, complex 1 shows the maximal emission at 379nm, which is considered to be the result of the intraligand transition of 3-PPDS (λ em =383nm). Differently, complex 2 displays an intense emission with the maximum peak at 404nm with an evident red-shift compared with the 2-PPDS ligand (λ em =389nm). One probable reason for the lower energy emission of complex 2 may be ascribed to the presence of Ag-S bonding interactions, which is presumably originated from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) .

<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Metallosupramolecular silver complexes with heterocyclic disulfide, {[Ag(<ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold>)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Ag(<ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold>)]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), have been structurally determined. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is composed of [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] macrocycle units and 1D purely inorganic [Ag(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> helical chains. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has a 1D extended structure with Ag–S bonding interactions, which is probably promoted by the close proximity in space between Ag atom and disulfide function.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Metallosupramolecular silver complexes with heterocyclic disulfide, {[Ag(3-PPDS)(NO3)]} n  (1) and {[Ag(2-PPDS)]ClO4} n  (2), have been structurally determined. Complex 1 is composed of [Ag2(3-PPDS)2] macrocycle units and 1D purely inorganic [Ag(NO3)] n  helical chains. Complex 2 has a 1D extended structure with Ag-S bonding interactions, which is probably promoted by the close proximity in space between Ag atom and disulfide function.

Preparation of [Ag(3-PPDS)(NO3)] n  (1) and [Ag(2-PPDS)(ClO4)] n  (2)

A colorless solution of AgNO3 (0.017g, 0.1mmol) in CH3CN (5mL) was carefully layered above a solution of 3-PPDS (0.039g, 0.1mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5mL). After 3 days light-yellow crystals were produced. Yield 61% (based on AgNO3). Anal. Calc. for C18H12AgN7O3S2: C, 39.57; H, 2.21; N, 17.95. Found: C, 39.52; H, 2.39; N, 17.75%. ν max/cm-1 3069m, 1593s, 1564s, 1537m, 1481m, 1430s, 1338s, 1203s, 1181s, 1038m, 1027m, 824s, 811s, 719s, 701s, 641s, 503w.

The preparation of complex 2 is similar to complex 1 but by reaction of AgClO4 with 2-PPDS. Yield 21% (based on AgClO4). Anal. Calc. for C18H12AgClN6O4S2: C, 37.03; H, 2.07; N, 14.40. Found: C, 37.21; H, 2.19; N, 14.35%. ν max/cm-1 3067m, 1590m, 1565s, 1540m, 1470m, 1445m, 1412s, 1349s, 1257m, 1182s, 1092s, 1006m, 819w, 793m, 759m, 715s, 646m, 622s.

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:section-title>Luminescent properties of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Solid state luminescent properties were examined for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at room temperature (see ). Upon excitation at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows the maximal emission at 379<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which is considered to be the result of the intraligand transition of <ce:bold>3-PPDS</ce:bold> (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>383<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm). Differently, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays an intense emission with the maximum peak at 404<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with an evident red-shift compared with the <ce:bold>2-PPDS</ce:bold> ligand (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>

One probable reason for the lower energy emission of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may be ascribed to the presence of Ag–S bonding interactions, which is presumably originated from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) .</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure description of complexes 1 and 2 

Macrocycle structures have been obtained by assembling 4-dpds with several metal ions (e.g. Pt, Ir, Co, Ni) , but Ag(I)-based macrocycles are still less known. Interestingly, assembly between AgNO3 and 3-PPDS generated complex 1 containing 2:2 M:L macrocycle units, of which each Ag atom is five-coordinated by three O atoms from two NO3 - anions and two N atoms from two 3-PPDS ligands ( (a)). Both Ag-O and Ag-N bond lengths are within the normal range, and the C-S-S-C torsion angle (89.55°) is comparable to that of the free 3-PPDS ligand (81.33°) as expected . Moreover, the macrocycle cavity has its dimension of 7.34×13.01Å measured by Ag⋯Ag and S-S⋯S-S separations. As most examples in literatures , complex 1 also crystalizes in a non-chiral space group (P2/1) due to the presence of 1:1 macrocycle enantiomers.

Albeit its poor quality, X-ray diffraction analysis unambiguously indicates that Ag-S bonding interactions have been established in complex 2. As depicted in  , each Ag(I) atom is bound to two set of NNS donor atoms from two 2-PPDS ligands with Ag-S bond distances of 2.753(4) and 2.729(3)Å, which are far shorter than the sum of Van der Waals radius of Ag and S atoms (3.52Å). Compared with the free 2-PPDS, the S-S distance (2.016(4)Å) of 2-PPDS in complex 2 is almost unchanged while the C-S-S-C torsion angle is altered significantly from 82.7° to 99.7° . Particularly, complex 2 has two types of five-membered chelated rings (CNAgNC and CNAgSS) sharing one common Ag-N edge. If treating the two fused five-membered rings as the repeating unit, the linkage between adjoining units could be classified into two types (1) sharing one common S-S edge with the Ag-S-S-Ag torsion angle of approximately 115.5°; (2) sharing one common Ag vertex with the S-Ag-S angle of 95.8°. Alternative use of two linkages produces a 1D extended structure, of which a unique Ag⋯S-S⋯Ag⋯S-S⋯Ag inorganic chain is resulted with the nearest Ag⋯Ag separation of about 5.71Å ( ).

Luminescent properties of complexes 1 and 2 

Solid state luminescent properties were examined for complexes 1 and 2 at room temperature (see ). Upon excitation at 300nm, complex 1 shows the maximal emission at 379nm, which is considered to be the result of the intraligand transition of 3-PPDS (λ em =383nm). Differently, complex 2 displays an intense emission with the maximum peak at 404nm with an evident red-shift compared with the 2-PPDS ligand (λ em =389nm). One probable reason for the lower energy emission of complex 2 may be ascribed to the presence of Ag-S bonding interactions, which is presumably originated from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) .
